content: Using NLP for Schizophrenia therapy Chatbots + Deep video portraits for Digitalized AVATAR therapy Mishaal LakhaniBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMar 29  Artificial intelligence has been used to completely change the game in the healthcare system. Specifically, computer vision in diagnosis and ANNs in processing the tons of data we have. But, what's not exactly in the headlines so often is the impact Natural Language Processing(everything to do with machines and language)will make on the medical side. One specific example of this is with treatment for people with schizophrenia, by augmenting a newer treatment to scale it. Schizophrenia is a HUGE problem, and that’s why I wrote an article about it and AVATAR therapy, so you can check it out here. To summarize the idea, the AVATAR treatment method can be replicated in a scalable and practical way using a chatbot like structure and enhancing it with deep video portraits. For this article, I’ll go in depth to explain what exactly NLP and specifically conversational ai is, how deep fakes work and how the cross-section of these two can create something super impactful. Big Money and Cutting Edge Technology: How Investment in AI/ML Will Revolutionize The Healthcare…Among remarkable developments in Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) over the last couple of years…www.datadriveninvestor.com Let's get chatty  Before we go into depth about Machine learning and NLP, let’s start with a more familiar concept. Nowadays, so many websites and commerce stores have a little speech bubble at the bottom of the page, whispering to click it if you have any questions. This button summons a genie that will answer your every question no matter what hour it may be- helps to really satisfy your late night e-commerce spree. Just kidding. But the chat bubble does summon a conversation with a chatbot, which can answer most of your generic questions more or less and doesn’t require a human on the other time A chatbot is a computer program that imitates human conversation — spoken, written or both. There are two types of chatbots: the standard rule-based bot that performs scripted actions based on keywords and the AI-powered chatbot, which uses machine learning to converse more naturally. Since the former only respond to specified commands, it only displays a fixed level of smartness. Give this kind of bot a command that it doesn’t understand, it won’t know what to do nor will it get any smarter with more interactions or information. A typical example of this would be Siri. You say “Hey Siri, I’m hungry” and you get the response “searching the web for results of dime banjo tea… okay here are the top answers” The second type of chatbot uses artificial intelligence, the ability to understand language (instead of just commands), and the ability to learn. This technology has led to intelligent chatbots that can discover new patterns and get smarter as they encounter more situations. Put simply, a chatbot’s job is to receive input data, interpret it, and translate it into a relevant output value. Upon receiving the input data, it must analyze and contextualize in order to determine the appropriate “reaction” to whatever prompt it has received. So Artificial intelligence is doing what exactly? AI, through NLP, ML and DL help the chatbots “learn” by finding and analyzing the patterns in data. They can apply these patterns to slightly different questions- basically having the intelligence to solve problems and do tasks without human interference Machine learning With ML the system learns by being exposed to lots of examples (rather than by being given more rules) and then learns more from the interactions it has. Machine learning uses algorithms, basically sequences of instructions telling computers what to do. Algorithms can be combined and sequenced in complex ways. When a chatbot receives an input, it must analyze it and form context so that it can determine the desired output. As the chatbot is trained by having a data input, it searches for patterns, which it can save for reference. This is the “learning” process. Deep Learning Deep learning is a type of machine learning that uses layered algorithms called an artificial neural network. The connections between the neurons are weighted by the prior learning patterns and events. The algorithms find patterns in vast quantities of data and infer how to respond to new data from these patterns. This approach is used in AI-based chatbots, where a predefined set of responses is not useful. The data can thus be thought of as a set of examples that specify the correct outputs for a vast number of given inputs. The machine’s job is to extract and store the patterns from the data. The chatbot continues to “learn” — that is, extract and save patterns — with each subsequent input of data. Natural Language Processing NLP is the third component of a chatbot’s intelligence and refers to its analysis and synthesis of human languages. “NLP makes use of predictive analytics, a combination of statistical, data mining, and data modelling techniques aimed at proactively generating information, without having to wait for a prompt from a human.” NLP gives a chatbot the ability to learn and mimic the styles and patterns of human conversation. But, NLP faces challenges, such as enabling the chatbot to deduce how the human user is feeling, a capability called sentiment analysis that employs language analytics. NLP is also split into two: natural-language understanding (NLU) and natural-language generation (NLG). Natural-language understanding is the complex process of taking human-language inputs and translating them into forms understandable by a machine.Natural-language generation is the reverse process: taking the computer’s generated output to a prompt and turning it into a form that is understandable by the human user. A chatbot’s level of intelligence is an umbrella term for its performance in several interconnected areas. An intelligent chatbot is typically one that’s capable of “learning” and using its experience to improve its performance.Bots created for narrower functions are intelligent if they’re able to identify desirable outcomes (a challenging task), plan a multi-step process to achieve these outcomes, and then work autonomously to meet them. This sequence of activities goes by the name of the “sense-think-act” process. In addition, bots need to know how to ask questions that will enable them to gather the information required to undertake all the steps.An intelligent chatbot also understands what a user wants and is prepared to meet users’ requests. Conversation bots are intelligent if they can handle different styles and topics of conversation with ease. An intelligent chatbot needs to understand the intent- the meaning behind the action, be efficient and clear and provide relevant information in return. How this all comes together  Okay makes sense. But how in the world can it help schizophrenia patients???? Well, I kinda advised reading the other article, but I’ll summarize it here anyways. TLDR, AVATAR therapy shows the same results as general Schizophrenia therapy but in half the time (12 weeks instead of 24). That's pretty important when Schizophrenia patients require the second longest amount of patient car (amount of bed spots it takes up) in any mental or physical illness. In AVATAR therapy, the schizophrenia patients worked with the therapist to create a computerized simulation (avatar) of the voice they most wanted to influence (from their auditory-visual hallucinations)– including what the voice said, how it sounded, and how it could look. Therapy involves a three-way conversation between the patient, therapist, and avatar with the therapist speaking as themselves and also voicing the avatar. The bot gradually becomes more open to accepting the patient to mimic real life situations In each session patients spent 10–15 minutes speaking face-to-face with the avatar, practicing standing up to it, correcting any misconceptions it had about them, and taking control of the conversation, so that power shifted from the avatar to the patient. The avatar came to recognize the patient’s strengths and good qualities, and the patient’s greater control and power in the relationship.
title: Using NLP for Schizophrenia therapy
content_html:
Using NLP for Schizophrenia therapy

Chatbots + Deep video portraits for Digitalized AVATAR therapy

Mishaal Lakhani
Mar 29

Artificial intelligence has been used to completely change the game in the healthcare system. Specifically, computer vision in diagnosis and ANNs in processing the tons of data we have.

But, what's not exactly in the headlines so often is the impact Natural Language Processing(everything to do with machines and language)will make on the medical side.

One specific example of this is with treatment for people with schizophrenia, by augmenting a newer treatment to scale it. Schizophrenia is a HUGE problem, and that’s why I wrote an article about it and AVATAR therapy, so you can check it out here.

To summarize the idea, the AVATAR treatment method can be replicated in a scalable and practical way using a chatbot like structure and enhancing it with deep video portraits.

For this article, I’ll go in depth to explain what exactly NLP and specifically conversational ai is, how deep fakes work and how the cross-section of these two can create something super impactful.

Big Money and Cutting Edge Technology: How Investment in AI/ML Will Revolutionize The Healthcare…
Among remarkable developments in Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) over the last couple of years…www.datadriveninvestor.com

Let's get chatty

Before we go into depth about Machine learning and NLP, let’s start with a more familiar concept.

Nowadays, so many websites and commerce stores have a little speech bubble at the bottom of the page, whispering to click it if you have any questions. This button summons a genie that will answer your every question no matter what hour it may be- helps to really satisfy your late night e-commerce spree.

Just kidding. But the chat bubble does summon a conversation with a chatbot, which can answer most of your generic questions more or less and doesn’t require a human on the other time

A chatbot is a computer program that imitates human conversation — spoken, written or both. There are two types of chatbots: the standard rule-based bot that performs scripted actions based on keywords and the AI-powered chatbot, which uses machine learning to converse more naturally.

Since the former only respond to specified commands, it only displays a fixed level of smartness. Give this kind of bot a command that it doesn’t understand, it won’t know what to do nor will it get any smarter with more interactions or information.

A typical example of this would be Siri. You say “Hey Siri, I’m hungry” and you get the response “searching the web for results of dime banjo tea… okay here are the top answers”

The second type of chatbot uses artificial intelligence, the ability to understand language (instead of just commands), and the ability to learn. This technology has led to intelligent chatbots that can discover new patterns and get smarter as they encounter more situations.

Put simply, a chatbot’s job is to receive input data, interpret it, and translate it into a relevant output value. Upon receiving the input data, it must analyze and contextualize in order to determine the appropriate “reaction” to whatever prompt it has received.

So Artificial intelligence is doing what exactly?

AI, through NLP, ML and DL help the chatbots “learn” by finding and analyzing the patterns in data. They can apply these patterns to slightly different questions- basically having the intelligence to solve problems and do tasks without human interference

Machine learning

With ML the system learns by being exposed to lots of examples (rather than by being given more rules) and then learns more from the interactions it has. 
Machine learning uses algorithms, basically sequences of instructions telling computers what to do.

Algorithms can be combined and sequenced in complex ways. When a chatbot receives an input, it must analyze it and form context so that it can determine the desired output. As the chatbot is trained by having a data input, it searches for patterns, which it can save for reference. This is the “learning” process.

Deep Learning

Deep learning is a type of machine learning that uses layered algorithms called an artificial neural network. The connections between the neurons are weighted by the prior learning patterns and events. The algorithms find patterns in vast quantities of data and infer how to respond to new data from these patterns. This approach is used in AI-based chatbots, where a predefined set of responses is not useful.

The data can thus be thought of as a set of examples that specify the correct outputs for a vast number of given inputs. The machine’s job is to extract and store the patterns from the data. The chatbot continues to “learn” — that is, extract and save patterns — with each subsequent input of data.

Natural Language Processing

NLP is the third component of a chatbot’s intelligence and refers to its analysis and synthesis of human languages. “NLP makes use of predictive analytics, a combination of statistical, data mining, and data modelling techniques aimed at proactively generating information, without having to wait for a prompt from a human.”

NLP gives a chatbot the ability to learn and mimic the styles and patterns of human conversation. But, NLP faces challenges, such as enabling the chatbot to deduce how the human user is feeling, a capability called sentiment analysis that employs language analytics.

NLP is also split into two: natural-language understanding (NLU) and natural-language generation (NLG).

  • Natural-language understanding is the complex process of taking human-language inputs and translating them into forms understandable by a machine.
  • Natural-language generation is the reverse process: taking the computer’s generated output to a prompt and turning it into a form that is understandable by the human user.
A chatbot’s level of intelligence is an umbrella term for its performance in several interconnected areas. An intelligent chatbot is typically one that’s capable of “learning” and using its experience to improve its performance.
Bots created for narrower functions are intelligent if they’re able to identify desirable outcomes (a challenging task), plan a multi-step process to achieve these outcomes, and then work autonomously to meet them. This sequence of activities goes by the name of the “sense-think-act” process.

In addition, bots need to know how to ask questions that will enable them to gather the information required to undertake all the steps.
An intelligent chatbot also understands what a user wants and is prepared to meet users’ requests. Conversation bots are intelligent if they can handle different styles and topics of conversation with ease.

An intelligent chatbot needs to understand the intent- the meaning behind the action, be efficient and clear and provide relevant information in return.

How this all comes together

Okay makes sense. But how in the world can it help schizophrenia patients????

Well, I kinda advised reading the other article, but I’ll summarize it here anyways.

TLDR, AVATAR therapy shows the same results as general Schizophrenia therapy but in half the time (12 weeks instead of 24). That's pretty important when Schizophrenia patients require the second longest amount of patient car (amount of bed spots it takes up) in any mental or physical illness.

In AVATAR therapy, the schizophrenia patients worked with the therapist to create a computerized simulation (avatar) of the voice they most wanted to influence (from their auditory-visual hallucinations)– including what the voice said, how it sounded, and how it could look. Therapy involves a three-way conversation between the patient, therapist, and avatar with the therapist speaking as themselves and also voicing the avatar.

In each session patients spent 10–15 minutes speaking face-to-face with the avatar, practicing standing up to it, correcting any misconceptions it had about them, and taking control of the conversation, so that power shifted from the avatar to the patient. The avatar came to recognize the patient’s strengths and good qualities, and the patient’s greater control and power in the relationship.

Using NLP for Schizophrenia therapy

Chatbots + Deep video portraits for Digitalized AVATAR therapy

Mishaal Lakhani
Mar 29

Artificial intelligence has been used to completely change the game in the healthcare system. Specifically, computer vision in diagnosis and ANNs in processing the tons of data we have.

But, what's not exactly in the headlines so often is the impact Natural Language Processing(everything to do with machines and language)will make on the medical side.

One specific example of this is with treatment for people with schizophrenia, by augmenting a newer treatment to scale it. Schizophrenia is a HUGE problem, and that’s why I wrote an article about it and AVATAR therapy, so you can check it out here.

To summarize the idea, the AVATAR treatment method can be replicated in a scalable and practical way using a chatbot like structure and enhancing it with deep video portraits.

For this article, I’ll go in depth to explain what exactly NLP and specifically conversational ai is, how deep fakes work and how the cross-section of these two can create something super impactful.

Big Money and Cutting Edge Technology: How Investment in AI/ML Will Revolutionize The Healthcare…
Among remarkable developments in Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) over the last couple of years…www.datadriveninvestor.com

Let's get chatty

Before we go into depth about Machine learning and NLP, let’s start with a more familiar concept.

Nowadays, so many websites and commerce stores have a little speech bubble at the bottom of the page, whispering to click it if you have any questions. This button summons a genie that will answer your every question no matter what hour it may be- helps to really satisfy your late night e-commerce spree.

Just kidding. But the chat bubble does summon a conversation with a chatbot, which can answer most of your generic questions more or less and doesn’t require a human on the other time

A chatbot is a computer program that imitates human conversation — spoken, written or both. There are two types of chatbots: the standard rule-based bot that performs scripted actions based on keywords and the AI-powered chatbot, which uses machine learning to converse more naturally.

Since the former only respond to specified commands, it only displays a fixed level of smartness. Give this kind of bot a command that it doesn’t understand, it won’t know what to do nor will it get any smarter with more interactions or information.

A typical example of this would be Siri. You say “Hey Siri, I’m hungry” and you get the response “searching the web for results of dime banjo tea… okay here are the top answers”

The second type of chatbot uses artificial intelligence, the ability to understand language (instead of just commands), and the ability to learn. This technology has led to intelligent chatbots that can discover new patterns and get smarter as they encounter more situations.

Put simply, a chatbot’s job is to receive input data, interpret it, and translate it into a relevant output value. Upon receiving the input data, it must analyze and contextualize in order to determine the appropriate “reaction” to whatever prompt it has received.

So Artificial intelligence is doing what exactly?

AI, through NLP, ML and DL help the chatbots “learn” by finding and analyzing the patterns in data. They can apply these patterns to slightly different questions- basically having the intelligence to solve problems and do tasks without human interference

Machine learning

With ML the system learns by being exposed to lots of examples (rather than by being given more rules) and then learns more from the interactions it has. 
Machine learning uses algorithms, basically sequences of instructions telling computers what to do.

Algorithms can be combined and sequenced in complex ways. When a chatbot receives an input, it must analyze it and form context so that it can determine the desired output. As the chatbot is trained by having a data input, it searches for patterns, which it can save for reference. This is the “learning” process.

Deep Learning

Deep learning is a type of machine learning that uses layered algorithms called an artificial neural network. The connections between the neurons are weighted by the prior learning patterns and events. The algorithms find patterns in vast quantities of data and infer how to respond to new data from these patterns. This approach is used in AI-based chatbots, where a predefined set of responses is not useful.

The data can thus be thought of as a set of examples that specify the correct outputs for a vast number of given inputs. The machine’s job is to extract and store the patterns from the data. The chatbot continues to “learn” — that is, extract and save patterns — with each subsequent input of data.

Natural Language Processing

NLP is the third component of a chatbot’s intelligence and refers to its analysis and synthesis of human languages. “NLP makes use of predictive analytics, a combination of statistical, data mining, and data modelling techniques aimed at proactively generating information, without having to wait for a prompt from a human.”

NLP gives a chatbot the ability to learn and mimic the styles and patterns of human conversation. But, NLP faces challenges, such as enabling the chatbot to deduce how the human user is feeling, a capability called sentiment analysis that employs language analytics.

NLP is also split into two: natural-language understanding (NLU) and natural-language generation (NLG).

  • Natural-language understanding is the complex process of taking human-language inputs and translating them into forms understandable by a machine.
  • Natural-language generation is the reverse process: taking the computer’s generated output to a prompt and turning it into a form that is understandable by the human user.
A chatbot’s level of intelligence is an umbrella term for its performance in several interconnected areas. An intelligent chatbot is typically one that’s capable of “learning” and using its experience to improve its performance.
Bots created for narrower functions are intelligent if they’re able to identify desirable outcomes (a challenging task), plan a multi-step process to achieve these outcomes, and then work autonomously to meet them. This sequence of activities goes by the name of the “sense-think-act” process.

In addition, bots need to know how to ask questions that will enable them to gather the information required to undertake all the steps.
An intelligent chatbot also understands what a user wants and is prepared to meet users’ requests. Conversation bots are intelligent if they can handle different styles and topics of conversation with ease.

An intelligent chatbot needs to understand the intent- the meaning behind the action, be efficient and clear and provide relevant information in return.

How this all comes together

Okay makes sense. But how in the world can it help schizophrenia patients????

Well, I kinda advised reading the other article, but I’ll summarize it here anyways.

TLDR, AVATAR therapy shows the same results as general Schizophrenia therapy but in half the time (12 weeks instead of 24). That's pretty important when Schizophrenia patients require the second longest amount of patient car (amount of bed spots it takes up) in any mental or physical illness.

In AVATAR therapy, the schizophrenia patients worked with the therapist to create a computerized simulation (avatar) of the voice they most wanted to influence (from their auditory-visual hallucinations)– including what the voice said, how it sounded, and how it could look. Therapy involves a three-way conversation between the patient, therapist, and avatar with the therapist speaking as themselves and also voicing the avatar.

In each session patients spent 10–15 minutes speaking face-to-face with the avatar, practicing standing up to it, correcting any misconceptions it had about them, and taking control of the conversation, so that power shifted from the avatar to the patient. The avatar came to recognize the patient’s strengths and good qualities, and the patient’s greater control and power in the relationship.

In the case of our Schizophrenia bot, we basically digitalized the 3-way conversation. Well, 2 parts of it. The bot is trained to be the voice/thoughts of the perpetrator and the therapist. The most important part here is really the therapist because this can be scaled for any medical professional to conduct it, not just a few specialized doctors.

This could work either with the patient directly interacting with the chatbot, or the doctor typing/use of NLP for speech to text. 
The perpetrator would say something -> the patient would respond -> this information would be recorded and used as data for following interactions -> the therapist would respond with words of encouragement or support.

Over time, through the sessions, the voice would become more submissive. A key part of this is using sentiment analysis to determine whether the patient is reacting well or not, and basing the therapist’s advice to be more assertive or not on the type of responses.

Currently, the data I’m using is comprised of some existant AVATAR therapy transcripts and other manually written dialogue from videos. This is nowhere near being enough to support super effective conversation and therapy. However, with more data being released and a base level source available now, it is still functional.

Bonus 🎉

So now that we have a basic understanding of conversational ai and how it will be applied, we can do a quick overview of deep fakes as well, the bonus part of the idea.

Deepfakes actually morph a person’s face to mimic someone else’s features and preserve the original facial expression. The procedure followed for this is here. When used properly, this technique allows for very realistic videos at a cheap cost. The ideal combination would be deep video portraits, which would allow for an even smoother flow and real time. You can check out a cool video explanation of them here.

This would be used as an alternative easier and more customizable method in comparison to the current, slightly cartoon-ish avatars used now. Deep video portraits would allow the doctor to make the desired facial expressions, in comparison to the standard mouth movement as well. This would definitely contribute to mimicking reality more accurately- one of the reasons AVATAR therapy has been successful in the first place.

So what does this all mean?

Overall, this is still far from perfect or deployable. As I mentioned above, the data and the tech is in its infancy right now. However, with the right effort and development, it has the potential to impact thousands.

Thank you for reading! If you enjoyed this article leave a few claps and follow my Medium and LinkedIn or check out my personal website to keep updated with my progress in AI.

  • Schizophrenia Treatment

title_html: Using NLP for Schizophrenia therapy
